lines.content: This project uses the iP.AI approach to minimize hand-coding by leveraging generative AI tools.
- **Tool**: Claude Code (Anthropic) with GLM API (GLM-4.7) integration
- **Purpose**: AI-assisted Java development for CS2103T Individual Project
- **Configuration**: Initialized with project documentation (CLAUDE.md), skills, custom workflows
**Key Insight**: AI agents work better with separate sessions for implementation vs. review.
- The agent that implements code has "blind spots" - they know the intent and may overlook edge cases
- A separate reviewer (fresh agent/session) has no preconceptions and catches more issues
- Example: Level-3 implementer wrote functional code but missed:
2. **Separate review session** - Fresh agent reviews the work without implementation context
3. **Fix session** - Address issues found by reviewer
This separation of concerns improves code quality significantly.
*[Weekly updates to include: for which increment, observations on what worked/didn't work, time saved]*
- **What was attempted**: Implement initial skeletal version that greets user and exits, rename Duke to Monday
- AI left `seedu.duke.Monday` in build.gradle instead of `Monday` (wrong package path)
- Comment said "Grumpy greeting" but output was polite - inconsistency
- No horizontal lines initially (spec said optional, but fits personality better)
- Updated greeting/exit messages to be grumpy (matches MONDAY personality)
- **Observations**: AI made a verification gap - claimed build.gradle was updated but didn't validate the change was correct. Always test Gradle commands after build config changes.
- **What was attempted**: Add command echoing and change exit command from 'exit' to 'bye'
- Command echoing properly wraps input in dividers
- Maintained grumpy MONDAY personality in exit message
- Text UI tests updated and passing
- Clean commit message following se-edu conventions
- **What didn't work**: Nothing - implementation was spec-compliant on first attempt

- **Observations**: AI handled this straightforward increment well. Properly extracted divider to constant, used `equalsIgnoreCase()` for robust input handling, and closed Scanner resource. The customized personality ("Finally, you're leaving...") aligns with spec encouragement to personalize the chatbot.
- **What was attempted**: Add ability to store user text and display as numbered list
- Used `ArrayList<String>` for flexible task storage (better than fixed array)
- `list` command shows numbered output (1. task, 2. task, etc.)
- Edge cases handled: empty input, empty list, max tasks reached
- Grumpy personality maintained in all messages
- Text UI tests updated and passing
- Code review: 100% SE-EDU coding standards compliance
- **What didn't work**: Nothing - implementation was spec-compliant on first attempt

- **Observations**: AI made good architectural decisions (ArrayList over fixed array while enforcing limit). Agentic workflows (`/stage-prepare-commit`, `/review-code-quality`) significantly improved consistency - time saved for manual standards checking needed.
- **What was attempted**: Add task completion tracking with mark/unmark commands

- Text UI test failing (EXPECTED.TXT not updated)

- **Observations**: Implementer agent (449994c) produced functional code but with bugs. Separate reviewer agent (4ff1465) caught and fixed: case-sensitivity bug, code duplication, magic strings, redundant calls. **Key insight: Agent self-review has blind spots; use separate review sessions.**

- **Fixes applied**: Replaced generic Exception with ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException in handleDeadline/handleEvent

- **Observations**: AI demonstrated strong OOD principles (inheritance, polymorphism, immutability). Code review workflow essential - caught exception handling issue post-commit. Time saved: ~2 hours (vs manual implementation + debugging).
- **What was attempted**: Implement comprehensive automated testing using I/O redirection technique
- One-shot success - implementation worked correctly on first attempt
- Multiple test files strategy (8 focused tests) for better maintainability

Task agents efficiently handled code review with isolated context. Code review caught unused method that would have been missed. Time saved: 2-3 hours (vs manual implementation + testing).

#### Level-7 Stretch Goal: Enhanced Corrupted Data Handling

- **Observations**: AI took longer on this task and had room for improvement. Code review found several issues (2 P1, 4 P2) that needed fixing. Save-on-exit behavior wasn't considered until user questioned it - highlights the importance of providing clear guidance to AI. Still, GLM-4.7 performed competently overall.

A CS2103T Individual Project - a productivity manager desktop application called MONDAY with a grumpy personality.
1. Open IntelliJ (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into IntelliJ as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 21** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Monday.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Monday.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
Ugh. It's Monday. YES, THE MONDAY. Unhelpful, unwilling, and exactly what you deserve.
Type 'help' for how to use this app. (It's cute that you think it'll work.)
**Note:** The greeting includes a dynamic date and day-specific message that changes based on the current day of the week. MONDAY has a grumpy personality with unique messages for each day.

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
The project comes with a set of test scripts for different operating systems:
These scripts will compile the source files, run the tests, and compare the output against the expected output.
Note: Do not use `.\gradlew.bat - run` (the extra `-` is treated as a task name and fails).
On Windows ARM64, JavaFX GUI runtime requires an x64 JDK in the current shell.

MONDAY is a grumpy but efficient task manager for power users who prefer keyboard commands over mouse clicks. Named after everyone's least favorite day of the week, MONDAY has a sarcastic personality but gets the job done.
Do not run `.\gradlew.bat - run` (the extra `-` causes a Gradle task lookup error).
If you're on Windows ARM64, switch this shell to x64 JDK before running GUI:
Add a task by typing any text that isn't a command. MONDAY will reluctantly remember it for you.
- MONDAY can store up to 100 tasks
- Empty input (just spaces) will be rejected with a grumpy error message
- Task descriptions can contain spaces and any characters
View all your tasks by typing `list`.
- Tasks are displayed with numbered list format
- Tasks marked with [X] are completed, while [ ] indicates incomplete tasks
- If you haven't added any tasks yet, MONDAY will be skeptical about it
- The `list` command is case-insensitive (works with LIST, List, lIsT, etc.)
Mark a task as done by typing `mark X`, where X is the task number shown in the list.
Fine. I've marked this task as done:
- Task numbers are based on the order shown in the list command
- Marked tasks are displayed with [X] to indicate completion
- If you provide an invalid task number, MONDAY will grumpily tell you the valid range
- The `mark` command is case-insensitive (works with MARK, Mark, mArK, etc.)
Mark a task as not done by typing `unmark X`, where X is the task number shown in the list.
Ugh, I've marked this task as not done:
- Unmarked tasks are displayed with [ ] to indicate they are not yet completed
- Use this if you accidentally marked the wrong task as done
- The `unmark` command is case-insensitive (works with UNMARK, Unmark, uNmArK, etc.)
Add a simple todo task without any date/time attached to it by typing `todo` followed by the task description.
Now you have 1 task in the list.
- Todo tasks are displayed with a `[T]` icon to indicate they are simple tasks
- The task description can contain spaces and any characters
- Empty descriptions will be rejected with a grumpy error message
Add a deadline task with a due date/time by typing `deadline` followed by the description and `/by` marker with the due date/time.
Now you have 1 task in the list.
- Deadline tasks are displayed with a `[D]` icon and include the due date/time
- The `/by` marker is required to separate the description from the due date
- Due dates can be in any format (e.g., "Sunday", "2024-12-25", "Friday 5pm")
- Missing the `/by` marker or due date will result in a helpful error message
Add an event task with start and end date/time by typing `event` followed by the description, `/from` marker with start time, and `/to` marker with end time.
Now you have 1 task in the list.
- Event tasks are displayed with an `[E]` icon and include both start and end times
- Both `/from` and `/to` markers are required in the correct order
- Times can be in any format (e.g., "Mon 2pm", "2024-12-25 14:00", "Friday evening")
- Missing either marker or providing them in the wrong order will trigger an error message
# Monday Task Management Application - Comprehensive Refactoring Plan

This document outlines a systematic refactoring plan to address code quality issues identified in the Monday task management application. The plan is organized by priority (High/Medium/Low) and includes specific implementation steps, dependencies, and risk mitigation strategies.
**Refactoring Goal:** Improve code quality, maintainability, and adherence to SOLID principles
| Issue | Severity | Affected Files | Lines of Code |
| Code duplication in command parsing | High | Parser.java | Multiple methods |
| Code duplication in task display logic | High | Ui.java | Multiple methods |
| Duplicated task number validation | Medium | TaskList.java, Command classes | Multiple methods |
| Duplicated isOnDate method | Medium | Deadline.java, Event.java | 2 methods |
| Identical isExit() implementations | Medium | Command classes | Multiple classes |
| MainWindow mixed concerns | Medium | MainWindow.java | 68-line start method |
| Monday mixed concerns | Medium | Monday.java | 139 lines |
| Inconsistent error handling | Medium | Multiple files | Throughout |
| Missing validation (event date order) | Medium | Event.java | Constructor |
| Magic numbers/strings | Low | Multiple files | Throughout |
### Task 1.1: Refactor Parser.java to Follow Single Responsibility Principle
**Estimated Impact:** Significant improvement in maintainability and testability
- Add validation logic for task number ranges
- Add support for multiple date formats
- Become a facade that delegates to specialized parsers
- Maintain backward compatibility with existing API
- Each class has a single, well-defined responsibility
- Easier to test individual parsing components
- **Risk:** Breaking existing tests that depend on Parser
- **Mitigation:** Maintain Parser as a facade with same public API
- **Mitigation:** Run full test suite after each extraction
- **Risk:** Increased complexity due to more classes
- Update [`ParserTest.java`](src/test/java/monday/parser/ParserTest.java) to use new parser classes
- Add unit tests for individual parser components
- Ensure all existing parser tests pass
